Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computer-Supported Math Discourse Among Teachers and Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This full research and development project is to design, develop, and test a cutting-edge learning environment where students and teachers solve mathematical problems and communicate their thinking with others through the virtual environment. The major focus is to increase the quality and quantity of significant math discourse among mathematics teachers and their students by using the virtual learning environment. The researchers will test the usability of the learning environment for engaging students in high quality discourse. The researchers will also examine the impact of the virtual learning environment on student significant mathematical discourse and achievement.

The project uses a design research method as well as summative evaluations to achieve research and development goals. Mixed methods will be used to examine the impact of the virtual learning environment on student significant mathematical discourse and achievement.

The findings of the project contribute to the field in three ways: (1) The virtual learning environment can be both an effective pedagogical tool and a research tool in mathematics education; (2) It will contribute to our understanding about the nature of mathematical discourse online as well as about ways to foster the quality and quantity of significant math discourse among teachers and their students; and (3) This project can provide insights into effective online deliveries of courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:This project integrated leading-edge cyber-learning-environment technology—Virtual Math Teams (VMT)—with an open-source dynamic geometry application, called GeoGebra, to create an innovative space for small groups of learners to collaborate exploring and resolving mathematical tasks. The project also developed a sequence of 55 related tasks that build learners dynamic geometry knowledge through tasks designed to be collaborative. The project's online environment and mathematical tasks are informed by current theories of the learning sciences concerning group cognition, instrumental genesis, and task design. The online environment and tasks were subject to a systematic iterative process of co-evolving the technology and curricular resources in the context of engaging, reflective learning experiences of meaningful mathematical discourse by in-service teachers and their students. Thereby, the project advanced theory, technology, and practice within real-world educational settings to forge a coherent research-based approach to mathematics education appropriate to today’s challenges and potentials.. 

Broader impact. The project designed, tested, integrated, evaluated and disseminated technology, curricular resources, pedagogical methods, and analytic tools for use in math-teacher professional- development programs, classrooms of mathematics students, home-schooling networks, online schools, and the Math Forum community (over three million visits per month). Project results support the use of mathematics exploration technology within collaborative math-discourse approaches at diverse schools entirely through their spread to in-service teacher-training programs and services—bringing practical cyber- learning of math to at-risk and isolated math students. It documents quantitatively and qualitatively the influence on both teachers and students in urban and suburban communities of this computer-supported math-discourse approach.
